author: MajorKoos

description.text: An array of small cubes across OpenSCAD's Z=0 plane provides a visual reference to simplify arranging objects on the build plate.

OpenSCAD displays the coordinate axes (tap Ctrl-2), but provides no indication of the model's actual size. When I arrange parts on the platform, this grid helps me position them correctly and provides a quick size check. The chunky set of parts show an actual build plate. They assemble into a rugged bicycle taillight mount (described at http://softsolder.com/2012/01/03/planet-bike-superflash-tour-easy-mount/) and required a bit of to-ing and fro-ing to position correctly. The cube() statement inside the nested for loops has the % prefix character (described on https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikibooks/en/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual/Modifier_Characters) that colors the cubes transparent gray and prevents them from rendering into the final model that becomes the STL file. As a result, the layout grid vanishes when OpenSCAD compiles and renders the object using CGAL (tap F6): the final STL contains only your model's parts. The image of the compiled sample shows just one lonely 2 mm cube at the origin: it's supposed to look that way! You should see an array of squares on the bottom surface of your build plate, because the bottom surface of the cube array lies exactly at Z=0. If you don't see the squares, then your objects extend below Z=0 and the extruder nozzle will gouge the platform. The default parameters produce a 100 x 100 mm array of 1 mm cubes, which is good enough for my purposes. If you're pushing the limits of your printer's build platform, modify the code to cover the full platform... and verify that your homing routine puts the (0,0,0) origin exactly in the middle of the plate. A few more details are at http://softsolder.com/2011/08/22/revised-openscad-layout-grid/.

An 350 H-Quad built from a combination of 3D printing plastic and 10mm carbon fiber tubes. This is an FPV capable drone that works with either the KK2.1 or Naze32 flight controllers.

Notes:
The carbon fiber tubes are friction fitted between 3D printed plastic that is compressed with 6-32 machine screws that can be found at any hardware store.

It's tough!
Unlike other 3D printed drones that can be damaged easily during a crash, this H-Quad was designed with convenient break points that make field repairs very easy. In fact, the prototypes that have been constructed are extremely resilient. The worst damage that has been inflicted is motor mounts that have either swiveled on the carbon tube or a broken motor plate zip tie, which results in the motor detaching without damage. After replacing the zip tie and repositioning the motor mount, the quad was back in the air!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

50%

Bill of Materials

Motors - EMax MT2204 (http://goo.gl/SdcgdZ)
ESCs - Micro 20A (BLHeli with Oneshot125 support)
Flight Controller - Naze32 Rev 6
2 Carbon Fiber Tubes 8mm x 10mm x 500mm (best pricing is on eBay)
6-32 Machine Screws (available at any hardware store)
Power Distribution Board (http://goo.gl/8GrucI)

Introducing the MRX H-Quad Construction

First choose if you're going to build the wider (KK2) or narrower (Naze32) configuration. I've found that the Naze32 provides a more stable flight.

1) Cut the 500mm carbon fiber tubes in half using a ceramic jigsaw or hacksaw blade. You should now have 4 tubes that can be laid out in the shape of an H (1 on each end and two in the middle).
2) Connect the tubes using 4 plastic T-connectors and 16 6-32 3/4" machine screws
3) Attach the motor mounts
4) Attach the motors to the motor plates using the screws included with the motors (note: this is different than the motor mounts)
5) Attach the motor plates to the motor plates using two zip ties
6) Solder your connections
7) Mount your power distribution board to the lower PD plastic piece and connect the PD plate to the carbon tubes
8) Mount your Flight controller to the flight controller plate making the connections to your ESCs, receiver, and depending on your configuration BEC
9) Finalize your electronic connections (motors to ESCs, FPV equipment, etc.)

Front - FPV Camera and T-Connectors / Motor Mounts Underside - Wires are routed through this area to keep a clean look Motor Mounts - Attached via 6-32 screws for strength. Motor plate (on top of mount) connected via zip ties so motors will detach during a crash instead of becoming damaged. Back - 3 panel LED lights helps with orientation Power Distribution and BEC are sandwiched between the top flight controller mount and the bottom plate. All parts are connected via 6-32 machine screws and are flush mounted making the screws generally invisible from a side profile. This is the reason carbon fiber is used. It's strong enough to hold a 10 year old's weight

title: 3D Wood Structure Trivet cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The drawing seems like a quite simple design, but it took some time to figure out the interlocking slots and the needed count of parts. Glued together the trivet is strong enough to carry a pretty heavy pot or pan.

This build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6 mm birch plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute.

A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to rebuild the design.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Household-Items/Trivets for more interesting trivet designs.
I used Solid Edge 2D Drafting to engineer the parts based on circles.

title: Round Ice Cube Mold with Pour Hole

description.text: This is my first project and I intend to use it. There isn't really much to explain, it's a mold for ice cubes, but I made it with Tinkercad and I am proud of it so here it is!

comments.text: Hey, I know you posted this a long time ago, but how successful were you? I've been working on something similar and I've had a very difficult time. My first prototype works, but won't release the ice without melting a bit. For my second, instead of a cube like yours has, I made it a thin sphere with a couple of "legs" on it in hopes that I could squeeze the legs to flex it a bit, making the ice release. That one wouldn't hold water, even after sanding the lip smooth. I'm about to go for round three, which is basically round 2 with a wide lip on it that tapers down to the thin sphere.

author: ThatSlyPanda

description.text:
Just another one ;-)

See how it flies: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0kYWvvdJrfI

Specifications
airfoil: KN209838/HM50T10% - twist: -5.5°
aerodynamic calculations: flight cpt. Florian Rösch
wing span: 1040 mm
wing chord: 173/130 mm
aerodynamic center 74 mm
wing overall weight: 310 g
wing area: 16,1 dm²
fuselage overall weight 270 g
wing loading: 36 g/dm²
longitudinal stability (Thies) STFs:
motor: Turnigy 2632 Brushless Motor 1000kv
motor camber: -3°
side pull: 2° right
propeller: Aeronaut CAM Aeronaut Carbon Classic 9 x 6.5" / 23 x 16.5 mm
static thrust: 500 g (3S Lipo)
battery: Turnigy nano-tech 950mah 3S 25~50C Lipo Pack
ESC: HobbyKing YEP 30A (2~4S) SBEC Brushless Speed Controller
receiver: OrangeRx R615X DSM2/DSMX Compatible 6Ch 2.4GHz Receiver w/CPPM
servos: Hitec HS-55

Print Settings
Attention
The wings are designed to print with 0.5 width, 0.3 hight and 2 bottom and top layer
If you print thinner, the perimeter of the upper side will not merge with the perimeter of the inner spars.
If you print thicker, the perimeter will not be printed continuesly in one turn.
The print must go as if you print in spiral vase mode. So you reach at least a smooth surface on the upper side.
If needed, you must try with 0.49 or 0.48 width. It depends on which slicer you use.
The second thing is, if you print with less layer hight, the inner spars will not connect the top and the bottom layer. There will be a gap inbetween.

All parts: layer height =0,3mm, width =0.5 mm
wing
1 perimeter, 2 bottom layer, 2 top layer, hollow
wing servo: 2 bottom layer, 2 top layer, hollow
aileron base: 5 bottom layer, spiral vase mode
aileron end: 2 bottom layer, spiral vase mode
aileron appendix: 1 perimeter, hollow
aileron interface: no bottom layer, spiral vase mode

fuselage
fuselage front: 7 bottom layer, 3 top layer
fuselage back: 3 bottom layer, 3 top layer
fuselage interface: 2 perimeter 0.4 no bottom/top layer, holow
fin: 4 bottom layer, spiral vase mode
fin cover plate: 2 bottom layer, hollow

Update 07.17.2016
The part "elevon_base_right_2.65.stl" was a wrong file!

Instructions

All sections of the wing are only hold together by two slightly elastic plastic cords inside the tubes.They are fixed with luster terminals on the wing ends.
There are only short joints to connect the parts.

Connectors 4 mm carbon tube
The holes for the connections are only parallel:

  1. In the middle, between the wing_center and the two wing_middle_rigth/left
    (50 mm in each side of wing_middle, 200 mm total at front tubes)
    (60 mm in each side of wing_middle, 220 mm total at rear tubes)

  2. At the servo segment
    (45 mm in the middle_wing and 25 mm in the wing_right/left (110 mm total at the front tubes)
    (50 mm in the middle_wing and 75 mm in the wing_right/left (165 mm total at the rear tubes)

  3. At the wing end
    (30 mm in the wing_right/left and 30 mm in the wing_end_right/left, 60 mm total)

The pipes must not be inserted deeper. There the holes bend and break very easily if you go deeper!

If you have to split the wing sections, the connectors will not be parallel, that means, you have to plug in the tubes one after the other, and see that you can get them out again, if needed. If both pipes are inside, the wings can not be pulled apart!

My plane was flown countless times but surely not with that high speed.
You will have noticed it, the wing is flexible as it is just stick together. If somethings break, like in your case, you can now easily exchange the broken part.
You are absolutely right, this plane is not designed for high speed.
You can increase the stability for more speed if you glue at least the middle parts.
I would be very happy if you upload your plane as a "Make", including your experience.

title: Rostock Max Flyingstruder Mount for E3D's Titan Extruder

description.text:
My original Fly'n'strude from tricklaser didn't fit or work well with the new E3D Titan extruder with a short-body nema17 13nCm motor. So I reimagined it.

You'll need to hit the hardware store and get some two 2-3mm threaded rods and nuts to bind the top and bottom plates together.

The holes are all 3mm, but you may need to drill bigger holes if need be.

I've recycled the original bands and the arm plate thingies that came with my flynstrude. Bungee cords can be used in place of the bands. If there is enough request, I guess I can reimagine the arm plates as well.

title: Rostock Max V2 Microswitch z-probe magnetic mount

description.text:
I've been using FSRs for a year as my zprobe. Even after much tweaking, it just didn't work as well. I've looked at other various zprobes, including the newest IR ones (which didn't work with my PEI bed). The hall-o effect probe just looked too complicated and I was too lazy to build it.

Having a ton of cheap microswitches laying around, just did a quick build on a mount for it. Works quite well with 626pilot's firmware with the smoothieboard.

There are 3 pieces. You need to print:

3x 4.8mm magnet m3-5 footer - this mounts to the effector plate arms using some short M3 screws.

3x 4.8 #6-10 which attaches to the top of the microswitch platform using #6 screws. Sorry for using the US screws, but I had a bunch laying around, and getting metric screws can be a pain sometimes.

1x microswitch lower platform.

You will also need 6x 3/16" cube n48 magnets. I got mine on the cheap from amazon, but I've seen them on ebay as well.

title: melitta mill and brew grinder lock paddle

description.text:
This is a replacement grinder lock for the Melita Mill and Brew coffee maker. I've had this coffee maker since 2003 (over 14 years), and really like the flavor of coffee it makes. Everyone that tries it says "wow, that's good coffee". However, the built-in grinder body has two locking levers that broke with years of use. You can get spare parts on ebay, but why not print them?!

The basket has two of these locks, so print one, and make sure it works for you before printing a second. To remove the old locks, use a flathead screwdriver to pry the old lock out, being careful not to break the axel nubs that let the part pivot to lock in place.

Update 11/17/2017
The first design could warp if printed with PLA, from the heat of brewing the coffee. I've improved the design, so that the heat from brewing doesn't deform the parts. It's now a two part, and should be printed at 100% infill. The plug fits into the paddle, after being installed in the grinder basket, to keep it from warping.

Instructions

  1. Print the paddle at 100% infill
  2. Print the plug at 100% infill
  3. Clean up the hole to fit the basket's pivots with a drill bit
  4. Mount the paddle in the basket, with the spring in place
  5. Push the plug into the paddle, to lock the two parts in
  6. Brew coffee

Download from Thingiverse, or find the files here:
https://github.com/thrasher/melitta_mill_and_brew

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini

Infill:

100%

Notes:

My prints were done with all of the default MakerBot Mini settings, except infill which must be 100%

Final Cleanup

I used a 1/8 drill bit to expand the holes on either side of the part, to match the axel nubs on the grinder body. On the MakerBot Mini, since it prints rafts, I used a metal file to cut down the outside surface raft and make it smooth. The hole size for the spring is a little loose, but it works fine. It required too much trial/error to get it exact, so I avoided that by making it slightly large.

Gently wedge the part on the axel nubs on the grinder body, and don't forget the spring! Work it back and forth a few times if it's a tight fit. Remove and use a file to cut down the shape further if it's binding. It shouldn't bind at all.
I just copied the existing broken part with a caliper, sketching it into Sketchup.

title: Bluetooth Headset Charger Siemens Gigaset S810

description.text:
This is a small housing for the electronic needed to charge a Bluetooth Headset using the power supply of the Siemens Gigaset S810.
The Gigaset S810 uses a power supply which is used to charge the mobile telephone. On the power supply a voltage of 4 V is given but the output is 7.2 V which is strange for a original part. So it is better to measure it. I uses this step down converter
http://www.ebay.de/itm/DC-6V-40V-To-5V-3A-Double-USB-Charge-DC-DC-Step-down-Converter-Module-DP-/111856162513?hash=item1a0b2596d1:g:IYQAAOSwZ1lWeW17
and this USB adapter
DELOCK Adapter USB micro-B male to USB2.0 A-male
needed to connect the Bluetooth headset.
To connect the converter to the power supply i simply connect it to the wire of the power supply.

In the first step I wanted to screw the housing for the step down converter to the base station of the mobile phone (this is why two holes are in the housing). At the end I glue it with plastic glue and it holds perfect.

title: Customizable Replicator Spool Holder with Filament Guide

description.text: Realized that I was using both a filament guide (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22649) and a spool holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20710/), but the filament guide was just wedged into place. By attaching the filament guide to the spool holder, it's held firmly into place. And by fitting into the slider in the parent design, the filament holder can be adjusted to suit the particular filament and spool.

Print the plate. It's designed to hold the left spool. Mirror it before printing to make a holder for the right spool. There are three pieces:
  • The "Wall" piece, which attaches to the Replicator
  • The "Spool" piece, which sticks out and holds the spool. It slides into the slot in the "Wall", nearer the outside edge of the printer.
  • The "Guide" piece, which slides into the slot in the "Wall", nearer the center of the printer. The filament guide helps prevent jams by pulling filament towards the center of the spool.
    • Assemble the three pieces, then put the tab into the back of the printer and rotate the holder down so that the rod sticks straight out, just like the standard MBI spool holder. Note that both pieces are designed to slide in the base plate so that they can be arranged as you prefer. When you load filament, slide the spool onto the rod, Then feed the filament through the hold in the guide, then into the usual tube.

title: Molten Plastic's Open Source Forced-Air Vapor Resurfacing System

description.text: This is my Open Source Version. This simple device will create a surface bond on your ABS objects. This bond is a 'skin' that fuses the outer surface of your 3d print and after hardening, your 3d printed object will become very strong. I printed a part the other day and stepped on it, it shattered and splintered into a million pieces of shrapnel. I took a duplicate of that part, ran it in the vapor machine for 25 minutes, let it harden overnight, and I can stand on the part. 'Nuff Said http://youtu.be/sspLS-6ww-I

The vapor machine consists of:  
1 x Square glass 1 gallon ice tea dispenser w/lid @ $19  
1 x variable speed 80mm case fan @ $4.99  
1 x scrap metal grill from old ATX psu @ $0  
1 x 5v Molex Power Supply @ $12  
This is a VERY simple machine.  Examine the sketchup file and look at my pics and my video  
When ready to use, pour half an ounce of acetone in the bottom of the chamber, close tightly and run the machine for at least 15 minutes and as long as the part can soften without deforming.  Remove and let harden for several hours.  
Be careful, acetone is flammable, has a low vaporization point but is very dense and lingers.

comments.text: Where did the iced tea dispenser come from?

comments.text: I am concerned about placing an unsealed electronic device capable of causing ignition in a highly flammable environment. Please use caution with this.
comments.author: ASD

comments.text: I have tested  this many times.  While Acetone is flammable, it does not combust explosively.  Due to its density, the flame is more like sterno than anything, and not even that explosive.  There are a great number of videos on Youtube which show how combustible it is, and what it takes to cause acetone to ignite.

I tried a very primitive vapor treatment using a asparagus cook pot

author: sirinebutikte

title: Water rudder for Piper Cub RC model.

description.text:
I made this for my 1:4,5 scale Piper Cub/L-4 Grasshopper with ESM Cessna 185 floats.

Print from something durable like nylon or PETG. Glue the two rudder halves together with CA or whatever you prefer. Add a suitable tension spring and some small screws.

Requires:
-One M3x50 mm bolt to be inserted from the bottom.
-Four small (~2mm/5mm) self tapping screws.
-One 10mm or longer tension spring. I made a short one by cutting a 50 mm long spring.
-Three screws of your choice for securing to the floats.

what is the cross between a pencilcase and a puzzlebox?
a lockable Puzzle-Case (with hidden drawers! :-) includes:
  • 3 rulers wich can be combined with joints to a 54cm ruler;
  • guiding rails in the main compartment - to use the rulers as seperator
  • two hidden drawers (need additional steps to unlock)
  • the key to lock the box is the pencil topper (literally)

the three print-sets are intended for one-color prints on a 20x20cm build area and include a 1x1x1cm calibration cube  
stl files for each individual part can be found in the zip file

comments.text: Has anyone made one of these?  I tried a few years back and about ripped my hair out trying and failing.

Vis magique , la même vis fonctionne avec des écrous gauche ou droite et avec des pas différents.

The same bolt can work with the following nuts:

Pitch of 40 mm to the right.
Pitch of 40 mm to the left.
Pitch of 80 mm to the right.
Pitch of 80 mm to the left.
Pitch of 160 mm to the right.
Pitch of 160 mm to the left.

comments.text: A quoi serve ce type de vis ? Je n'est jamais vu quelque chose comme ca.
comments.author: joepotato420

comments.text: Pour le moment ce type de vis ne sert à rien mais on ne sait pas, peut-être que quelqu'un va lui trouver une application. J'ai fait imprimer par des méthodes industrielles avec le moins de jeu possible la vis magique N°5. Les frottements sont tellement réduits que les écrous se vissent tout seuls par gravité. On pourrait imaginer une application pour transformer un mouvement rotatif en mouvement linéaire, pour le transport d'une tête d'impression par exemple.

title: 4 servo walking robot base controled by servo tester

description.text:
I wanted to make a Old school type robot with the glide slide walk action using 4 servos and a servo tester as the manual and automatic controller. The servo testers are so cheep, under $2 bucks on ebay and the 9g servos are so cheep that it just seemed like a good idea.
So here are the STL files for the feet, ratchets, legs and body/battery box mount.You can see the base unit in action on You Tube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FSefJ1_X-xs
Part 2 here. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6vNu6KSr4UI&feature=youtu.be
Or follow the Project on Alphadrome.
http://danefield.com/alpha/forums/topic/18899-alpha-strider-a-new-3d-printed-robot-project/

remixed_from.title: NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory

description.text:
PVC comes in extremely helpful with projects. Making a water tight seal between and securing it into place can be problematic. It will thread onto the standard 3/4" threading for PVC pipe. This is slightly different than what you can purchase at a store- it will thread all the way down despite the taper; hence, it requires a ruber washer for a water tight seal. I have used this on two different projects and it has worked great. I used it to rebuild the drainage system for an AC and then for an automatic watering system for plants outside. Worked great for both parts. Simply apply a rubber washer.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jZMnsMA3muk

title: Rostock-Mini PTC Bowden hotend adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: If you want to use a push to connect fitting instead of a simple M4 nut to hold your bowden tube on top of the hot end on a rostock-mini, this part is for you.

Print the part. Drill out and tap the center hole for the size of threads on your PTC adapter. Note: I wanted to be able to disconnect my bowden tube from either end without unscrewing the plastic part holding my M4 nuts in place, which is why I built this part and switched over to PTC connectors in the first place. The M4 nut approach works just fine otherwise.  
However, my POS PTC connectors don't "release" my bowden tube without breaking, so I still have to unscrew this hotend adapter piece to remove the tube....make sure you purchase quality PTC fittings for this part, or just keep using the M4 nut version of bowden tube adapters.

author: summetj

description.text:
This is a bed profile for the Geeetech Aluminium printer for Simplify 3d.

To use this in Windows:

  1. Copy the GeeetechAl.stl file into your c:\users\yourusername\Appdata\Local\Simplify3D\S3D-Software\ folder.
  2. Open Simplify3D and from the menu :
    Tools\Options and select the Machine tab.
  3. Towards the bottom, click the "Add" button and select the GeeetechAl.stl
  4. The name will appear in the list as per the image 2 above.
  5. Click OK to close the dialog and the bed will appear.

You need to do this just once.
Mac users - tough!

If the profile does not fit your bed profile correctly then do this:
You need a program like netfabb basic (free). Open it and load your model. Now adjust the X,Y,Z of the model so that the netfabb yellow bed (with squares) is exactly the correct X,Y,Z size/location. Once happy, then rt. click and "Save As" the repositioned STL and use that STL instead of the one I posted. It will now be correct in S3D.

Note: If your bed is smaller/larger you can resize the STL in netfabb and then export, before setting it up in S3D.
Created the bed and name and exported as STL. Opened and re-positioned in netfabb, exported the finished positioned STL.

title: 2nd Gen Subaru Legacy Rear Speaker Spacers (mounting brackets)

description.text:
These brackets allow you to install aftermarket speakers into the rear doors of a 2nd Generation Subaru Legacy (1995-1999). The rear doors on this generation of Legacy uses different bolt spacing than all other Subarus. I designed and made these brackets because I couldn't find anyone else that made them for this generation of Legacy.

I was able to fit 6.5" Alpine (SPS-610) speakers in the rear doors of my Subaru Legacy using this spacer.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30

Notes:

no supports or rafts are needed. If using ABS I found that printing with a wide (25mm) brim can help prevent the tabs from warping.

I recommend printing with several upper and lower layers and infill of at least 30% since your self-tapping screws will need to bite into this to hold your speaker to the spacer.
For installation you'll need to use longer screws than what was used by the factory. You'll also want to use shorter self-tapping screws to hold your aftermarket speaker to the spacer.

title: Multiple Filament Management for Da Vinci Printers

description.text:
This is for Da Vinci printer owners who have obtained a chip resetter, are using external filament spools, and are tired of having to fish a new filament through the printer's cover slot, and then feed it manually through the guide and into the extruder at each filament change..

This Thing includes a feed-thru guide that will fit the extra hole in Da Vinci single-extruder printers, and three additional "manifolds" that snap into the rectangular opening just below the factory-installed guide(s) inside the rear of the printer. Use the one best suited to your needs: 6, 8, or 15 openings.

To keep track of several different filaments that are pre-loaded, there are also three different retainers, with 6, 8, and 13 slots to receive and retain filament ends inside the printer, ready for quick filament changes.

I began with the six spool arrangement shown in the photos, but my installation has evolved into one using the 15-hole guide and two of the 8-slot retainers, one mounted on each side of the printer's interior.

Printer:

XYZ Da Vinci AiO 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Good

Infill:

Default

These are all simple parts, suitable for use immediately after printing. The filament guides simply press and snap into place, and I used 3M double-stick foam tape to fasten the retainers to the surfaces indicated in the photos.

I usually trim the filament ends immediately after unloading; this makes it easier to insert them into the retainer, and makes them ready for their next use.

My filament spools reside on shelves behind the printer, but any arrangement that allows the various filaments to be fed in through the slot below the rear of the top cover should work fine.
123D Design software. Nothing too difficult here.

The endstop switches used in the K8200 are sometimes triggered during a print when the frame is vibrating too much.
This happens mostly during zig-zag-filling of small perimeters and when using hexagonal infill with higher speeds.
It has the nasty side effect of misaligning all layers printed after the endstop is triggered, often ruining the print. Basically, the X- and Y-motors are executing a movement command and are interrupted by the endstop triggering, cutting off the power supply to the motor since the printer thinks the end of the print bed is reached. So the remaining movement is not executed, but discarded, leaving the print head in a position a distance away from where it should be. Sometimes this is only a small offset, but it can reach several millimeters or even centimeters when you're unlucky enough. One cause is that the endstop switch is actually triggered by the actuator (the small metal tongue) which hits the switch with enough speed to 'click' it. Another cause is that the connectors from the endstop switches to the controller board are sometimes loosing contact due to the vibrations. This happens when you unplug them too often and they start to wear out. This problem is indicated by the appearance of log messages looking like this: 16:33:45.089 : echo:endstops hit: Y:0.17
...
16:48:45.045 : echo:endstops hit: X:0.04 Note: only messages generated during a print are a problem, obviously not the ones while homing the axes. I heard there exists a patched firmware that ignores endstops during a print, but I don't like this idea. The endstops are there to prevent physical damage to the printer, so circumventing them is IMHO not so clever. My solution for this problem is twofold:
1) Stop the endstops from firing due to vibrations. (see the pictures)
-You need two strips of soft, elastic material (like protective envelopes or a thin sponge), about 4cm x 1cm (2.5 inches x 0.4 inches).
-Fold a strip twice lengthwise so you get a thicker package about 1 cm square.
(you could also use a thicker elastic material and use it unfolded, of course)
-Punch a hole in the center through all 4 layers, diameter about 4 mm.
-Slide the package over the micro switch actuator (metal tongue), be careful that you do not slide it down in the wrong orientation, this could prematurely trigger or even block the switch.
-Do this for the X- and Y-endstop switches. The Z-endstop is not affected by this problem.
-After installing, check the functionality of the endstops. Do not use big movements towards the endstops before you made sure everything works as expected.
2) Ensure the connectors are not loosing contact to the controller board. You could carefully bend the connector pins to ensure better contact and tie the cables together to stop the vibrations from reaching the connectors. (see last two pictures)

The screw used to adjust the Z-axis endstop is (according to the K8200 construction manual) installed upside down. That means the screw head is located (when Z-axis is homed) directly on the Z endstop switch.  
This is very inconvenient when you want to adjust the Z-axis. I simply installed the screw the other way around, making Z-axis adjustment an easy task.

I had some trouble with the motor stepper drivers overheating during long prints.  
They switch to emergency mode when they overheat, basically this means they disable micro-stepping and move only full steps.  
This will almost always ruin the prints, since the cohesion along the axis is lost and the object will either look pretty bad or rip open during or after printing.  
The fan I use is a radial 80mm fan from a PC with slot attachment. It cooled my graphics card 9 years ago. I simply removed the slot attachment and use some zip ties and drilled holes to attach the fan to the frame near the controller board.  
I rigged up an old 12V power supply and it was ready to go.  
The outlet blows directly through the piggiback-'tunnel' where the stepper drivers are mounted.  
I'm planning to design a PCB cover with matching air intakes to further improve cooling should the need arise.

All the scrapers I printed/used broke rather easily. Or the blades would just fall out. So far this one is holding up quite well, but time will tell. Just slide in the razor blade from the side.

I am using blades from American Safety Razor Company, these are slightly thicker, stronger, sharper than the cheap blades. If you have the thicker blades, use the heavy duty model. If you're wanting some awesome blades, buy these!

Note: I think it's okay for the blade to wiggle a little bit if it turns out that yours does. Upon scraping the pressure seems to lock the blade in place. You could probably superglue in a blade if you wanted to. These print pretty fast due to the thin walls. The shape gives the scraper additional strength.

My fan is currently not working to help cool the PLA as it prints. When doing small prints like this it doesn't cool fast enough without it. So these last couple of prints don't look the best in the overhang areas.

description.text:
Driver's inside door handle housing and handle itself broke off, or was broken when I was gifted this truck. Here's my fix! You'll see the first draft which was just a placeholder to see if the overall size was good. Good enough for me! I did adjust the height of the layers since there was a bit of a gap between each layer but still held up. I dropped each layer 1 mm on the next rendition and rounded a number of piece better. The cut outs for the cable and cable stop screw hole aren't perfect. Instead of going back to the drawing board I pulled out the drill and angle grinder. I also had to sand on the handle pivot end to slide around easy. The handle does pop out at times, but if you're mindful with pulling the handle and pushing it back in...no worries. Otherwise, feel free to modify and fix my design!

All in all, it works!! And it's strong!!

On a scale of 1-10 how difficult was this design?
Im new to 3d printing and am trying to design and print car door handles and emblems

comments.text:
maybe 6
i only went through 2 iterations on this which for me, a novice in design and 3d printing, i think is pretty darn good. I watched a bunch of youtube videos. learn your machine, learn the tolerances. my advice is to design items for use w/ real world items. design a panel that you will insert bolts or screws or etc into. then print and see if it actually works. generally people say if your item is 5mm, you should design a port hold for it at 5.3mm. i found on my machine i need more...ctc dual clone. Play around, buy alot of filament and you'll get it :) then you'll take those tolerances and apply them to your own designs and machine's capability. also...don't print a 14hr print unless you've done these tolerance and fitment tests first. you can waste a lot of time and money only to find out the piece is beautiful but the darn bolt doesn't fit

title: Cobblebot Basic dual blower print fan bracket

description.text:
This bracket mount is designed to slide onto the long edge of a Cobblebot Basic/Beast carriage, and has two pockets angled just downward enough to ventilate the part extrusion zone with a pair of 5015 style blower fans (aka centrifugal or squirrel fan, 50mm diameter, 15mm deep). The fan angle also permits them to pass under the gantry rail when moving to Y maximum position.

For this build, I used the following fan:
http://www.amazon.com/Brushless-Cooling-Computer-3D-Printer/dp/B00THZK270

Printer:

Cobblebot 1A

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Print in ABS, Nylon or other filament that won't go soft while suspended over a hot bed for hours.

If you are having trouble fitting your blower motors into the bracket, or if they are too loose and flop about, adjust the two commented lines in OpenSCAD that say "tightest possible fit" to exactly fit your blower motor's mount tab.

Assembly and installation

Insert blower housing tab nearest the exhaust into the mounting bracket, with the exhaust pointing toward the same direction as the arch in the middle of the bracket. Secure with an M3 x 25mm screw. Before installing an optional second fan, you will need to slide the bracket through the space between the Y rail and the belt that drives the carriage.

Slide the mount onto the long edge of the carriage that faces toward the Y maximum direction. You might need to trim or reposition the zip ties holding the belt to the carriage (and/or trim the mount bracket) to get it to seat against the carriage edge. Use a single 2.5mm zip tie through either side of the carriage belt slot to fasten the center of the bracket against the carriage.

After installation, gently verify your printer can move to all four corners of the X/Y gantry. At Y maximum position, the fans may stick out several millimeters beyond the outside of the frame (including outer Z wheels). Don't allow the fan to run into something such as a close proximity chamber/wall -- if you need to, trim off the unused outward facing tab on the blower housing.

Unfortunately you cannot put this bracket on the carriage side facing Y minimum -- it may interfere with homing operations depending on your Y home switch setup.

Part designed in four 2.5D slabs (DXF format) using Qcad, then extruded and stacked in OpenSCAD. It's ugly, and it works.

If you plan to rework this, save the OpenSCAD and DXF files together in the same folder. Most of the OpenSCAD geometry uses decent formulas, but the screw and mount pockets have a bit of fudge factor values, and while they aren't perfect, they met the needs for my assembly.

description.text: It's a better keyfob to hold F3 or F5 iButtons on your keyring. It's curved and it just feels nice :)

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used PETG as the material. PLA works as well, but PETG's flexibility makes it stronger.

You can change the shell thickness to 2.4 to save a lot of time in printing. If you do this, the infill setting barely matters because most of the material is the shell now :)

Version 1.x is rotated 105 degrees to put it upright on the bed. Version 2.x is printed on it's side.

When editing the thing in OpenSCAD, you may want to set $fn to 32 to save render time when previewing and set it back to 128 for the final render to STL. The hull() takes quite a bit of effort.

RevSpace

I just became a member of RevSpace, a hackerspace in Den Haag (The Hague) in The Netherlands. Our Doorduino uses iButtons and those come with pretty standard keyfobs like these.

RevSpace keyfob

They aren't as sturdy as they should be (a part of mine broke off and I had to duct-tape it). And because it is flat, it is not very easy to press it against the reader.

The upside is that you can easily swap the iButton for another one.

DUWO/Salto

I live in a student dorm, and the place has iButton-like keys for the building front door and each floor, and the indoor bike shed (being dutch all the way ;) ). They are made by Salso Systems. This keyfob looks like this one:

Salto keyfob and scanner

These are much more sturdy (I'd say unbreakable). Because they are curved, they are easier to scan.

Downside: you can't swap the iButton for something else.

I fixed it!

I took the best from both designs. Curved and sturdy like the Salto, and replaceable like the original RevSpace fob.

I fired up OpenSCAD, and tried a few things. At first it was hard to get the position on the print bed right, and my first attempt had ugly support stuff everywhere. Also, my first version was too thing ans very flimsy.

But then I tried it upright. By accident rotated it not 90 but 105 degrees, and that turned out to be just perfect. No supports needed!

Version 2.0

or that is what I believed for a while. I printed a few and some of those broke because the 1.x design depended too much on layer adhesion to stick together. I changed the design to have a flat side and printed it sideways. This is version 2.0. It seems to be a lot stronger now.

My Bump Knob kind of disintegrated on me today. Go to the lawnmower parts store? Not today. A little measuring; a little OpenScad; A couple of test prints, Wola. Problem solved, at least from a proof of concept standpoint. I am not sure how it will hold up.

It's been a month or two. It seems to be holding up pretty well.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

3

Notes:

The bolt that it has to fit is about 18 mm tall. The barrel of the shaft measured across the threads is about 8 mm. The Head of the bolt is about 13 mm measured from one flat side to another. The bolt head is about 5 mm tall.

As this is a proof of concept I printed mine at about 4% fill. I am going to see how it wears and up it as need.

It takes about 3.5 meters of filament. At 40/80 speed, it prints in about 35 minutes.

If there is a demand for other sizes, I will put a customizer version together and publish it.

04/2017 - second round.
The print broke near the hex nut.
I am doing a new print in pla.
20% fill instead of 4%,
and 6 shells,
the estimated build time is up to 45 minutes.
It might be useful to print a hex plug that you can glue into place so that the bolt doesn't fall out.

description.text:
This is a handy little mounting plate for those 12mm micro gear motors that are popping up everywhere. These little DC motors can be used in a lot of places where you would normally use a servo or continuous rotation servo motor, especially for robotics applications.

As an added bonus, I included some shaft adapters with a variety of shapes. I will post the shaft adapters as customizable parts in a separate post.

If you don't already have some of these motors, my favorite version is the Pololu Micro Gear Motors (https://www.pololu.com/category/60/micro-metal-gearmotors), which come with carbon brushes and a range of gear ratio options from 5:1 up to 1000:1.
The ones I have personally used with this mount are:

6V, 75:1 - http://amzn.to/1VOzb0w
6V, 100:1 - http://amzn.to/1NnaXrn
6V, 298:1 - http://amzn.to/1UIH7PB
6V 1000:1- http://amzn.to/1Oixkt7
Please note that the 1000:1 motor has a slightly longer gear box. The SCAD file alows you to adjust that, but if you only download the STL, it won't fit with the 1000:1

...OR... if you don't want to spend $15-$20 per motor, here are a few other manufacturers making similar motors at a lower cost:

6V, 300RPM: http://amzn.to/1Zs7NUe
12V, 100RPM: http://amzn.to/1VOyZhM
6V, 30RPM: http://amzn.to/1Oix8dn

description.text: A single floating aquaponics/hydroponics seeder. Floats nicely but with a full grown plant might sink, so will be working on design in next few weeks depending on growth and any issues I see. I'm growing lettuce at this time. I used the waste filament I collect to keep the seeds inside the unit. A small piece of paper towel keeps the tiniest of seeds in place until they sprout. Once they sprout the filament waste should hopefully do great to replace the peat moss. I was too lazy to go to Home Depot for it, but thought this repurposed waste might really work. These are night pictures...when I do most of my tinkering! Temps turned up a bit to make the stringing effect, should do well to hold the plant in when the roots get established. OK it was a mistake and we'll see how it plays out :)

description.text: A 6-dart Strongarm Cylinder, just slightly modified my 9-dart cylinder design as per request. For more information see the page for my 9-dart cylinder.

This is a thread compatible replacement top for Makerjuice resin containers.

Makerjuice resin is fantastic, but the bottles... can be a little hard to finagle into your printer, and even harder to pour from without spilling all over. You could use a funnel, but that's another piece to clean up and keep track of, so I thought there had to be a better way. Hence this top.

The threads will print without support, and there's a gap between the bottom of the object and the beginning of the threads so even if you have dimensional accuracy problems with your first layer or two it won't cause problems.

The top will seal against the bottle, and the top's cap should be tight enough to seal well but not so tight you can't get it off, if yours comes out too tight run a knife over the tip of the bottle topper to shave off a few tenths of a millimeter until it fits better.

And don't forget to print it in something the resin won't dissolve!

description.text:
This design was inspired by my earlier Shark Wrench (Poseidon's Pet).

This toy prints well in PLA and ABS. I have printed it successfully at 75% scale (~18cm) and 100% scale (~27cm). Printing it less than 75% may be difficult as the gears might lose fidelity. If you do get successful prints that are less than 75% scale please let me know.

I print the Gear Screw and Abdomen Gear at low speeds.

Assembly requires a screw and preferably a washer.

Drill a hole through the abdomen gear and the crank that allows your screw to spin freely (look for guide holes). Drill a smaller diameter pilot hole in the middle of the body (flat portion, look for guide hole) to ensure that plastic will not split, but will hold screw snuggly.

When screwing the Gear Shroud to the Body, make sure the Abdomen Gear is seated properly in the Gear Shroud, and that the Crank is seated properly behind the Gear Shroud and locked properly to the Abdomen Gear.

The Gear Shroud has a threaded connection to the Skull (like a jar lid). Tighten the Gear Shroud as loose as possible while making sure that it is tight enough to turn the Gear Screw. Over tightening may break the Gear Screw. A little white grease on Gear Screw will help to make the jaw movement smoother.

The Jaw is printed in two pieces (Jaw and Jaw Screw). They fit together by means of a Dovetail connection. It is fairly snug (no glue required).

This toy had a lot of design changes. It cost me many months and a few spools of filament. In the end, I think it was worth it. It looks pretty good, and gets a lot of compliments.

To see the DevilFish in action, and how to assemble you can check out this video.
https://youtu.be/7hATmZmMOy0

Special thanks to Thanks to Dan Kirshner for Thread Library and Jeremy Green for the Dovetail library.

I have also include the OpenSCAD file if anyone is interested.

description.text:
Tired of your AR-15 Magazines cluttering up valuable space in your gun safe? Wait no longer! Now you can store your Magpul Gen M1, M2 or M3 Polymer magazines also know as Pmags conveniently where your couldn't before leaving you the clean and functional safe you always wanted. These "Pmag Racks" are very versatile. Mounting options allow you to mount them virtually anywhere and the magazines will slide into the rack in any 1 of 11 configurations, Not counting a floor mounted application of course;
(Left Wall) Slide in forward or Down
(Right Wall) Slide in forward or Down
(Back Wall) Slide in Left to Right, Right to Left or Down
(Ceiling) Slide in Left to Right, Right to Left, Forward or even Back towards you!

These racks have mounting holes to accept #4 countersunk wood screws. The bottom of the magazine simply slides in and is held by gravity, also allowing you to also store your magazines with dust covers attached making your magazines readily available to be deployed for your next day at the range.
Sketchup and .STL files attached for the "Pmag Racks" that will hold 1,2,or 3 magazines to accommodate your storage solutions.

Remember it is your responsibility to store firearms safety and deter any unauthorized access to your firearms and ammunition. Be smart, lead by example and don't be the one to give shooting sports and your 2nd amendment right something to frown upon.

Small Tool Makers Vise.

This vise is designed in OpenSCAD and is fully customizable.

Bill of Materials
Threaded Rod (1x)
Nuts that match threaded Rod (3x)
Machine Screws and matching nuts (2x)

For the model shown I used a 5/16-18 threaded rod approximately 100mm long with 3 matching nuts.

To fasten the movable jaw to the movable jaw clamp I used 2 M3x25 machine screws and nuts

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

MakerFarm i3V 10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm or less

Infill:

20-25%

Isometric of Tool Makers Vise Base of Vise. Movable Jaw. Hole down the center is for a captive nut. The captive nut should spin but will allow for the movable jaw to be moved forward and backward Movable Jaw clamp. Use machine screws to connect the movable jaw to the movable jaw clamp Knob for the end of the threaded rod. Insert a nut into the bottom of the knob, then fix the knob to the threaded rod

Step 1) Insert 1st nut into the hexagonal hole in the vise base. Use an adhesive to glue the nut in place

Step 2) Insert 2nd nut into the hexagonal hole in the bolt knob, again use an adhesive to glue the nut in place.

Step 3) Place 3rd nut in the center hole of the moveable jaw.

Step 4) Insert two small machine screw nuts into the captive nut slots in the movable jaw. Place the moveable jaw in the vise base and fasten the movable jaw to the movable jaw clamp using the two machine screws.

Step 5) Place Loctite on the end of the threaded rod. Thread the threaded rod into the nut inserted into the bolt knob. Once the Loctite has set on the knob, thread the rod through the nut in the back of the vise base. Add Loctite to the other end of the threaded rod and thread the nut inside the moveable jaw.

description.text:
This is a functional desk model of a shrouded ducted fan, based on odie_wan's original model.

Up-scaled to accommodate 2x 50mm fans and rotated to ensure fans vent to the rear. Removed the flat bottom and designed a simple display mount to route the power cable through, with keyed fittings for stand and bottom of shroud.

My finished version used simple 3mm screws to hold the two halves together once the fans were installed. Printed in blue ABS and blemishes, square alternate wiring hole on side was filled with ABS sludge, the shroud join was patched with ABS sludge and then all sanded back down prior to painting. Painted with aluminium spray paint, lightly sanded and then finished with clear gloss.

Note that in my completed model, I used ABS sludge to fill and hide the middle join and the square cable hole on the side, before preparing for painting.

Designed for people with old land rovers like Defender/ Perentie/ County/ series 2/ series 3/ series 3A.

These old vehicles have a hand throttle, which is literally a knob attached to a cable running to the foot pedal.

In a new vehicle these function well, but in a vehicle like mine that's 26 years old - they slip as you hit the bumps. The army trick was to wedge a small block of wood under them.
This was effective, but not as easy to remove in a hurry, and didn't offer any adjust-ability.

This little design is pretty simple, and requires a single 3mm screw to secure it.
there have been a number of revisions to this design, I highly recommend that you try the "rounded V3.stl"

Please note that this device will prevent your engine revs from dropping when you lift your foot.

Source files included for your modding pleasure.

It goes without saying that:

I am not responsible or liable in any way shape or form for any misfortune, injury, loss of life or income/posessions as a result of using this item.

Use it at your own risk.

I make the assumption that if you are old enough to drive, you are old enough to make a wise choice about your own safety - and that you should know what you are doing.

comments.text: I like this idea, on my 1986 Land Rover OneTen V8 petrol this knob is for the Choke and it is pretty worn. A word of warning though: while applied on the choke it might also function sort of as a cruise control up to about 50 km/h, but it will not do your fuel consumption any good. So if you want to use this as a hand throttle, make sure it is actually connected to the throttle and not to the choke!

This is pretty nifty three dimensional cosine/sine wave made with OpenSCAD! Each individual unit is a cylinder, with height depending on a trig function and coordinates. The color of each cylinder is also generated with trig functions depending on their coordinates on the plane. I used cos for their red values, sin for green, and cos, sin and tan all for the blue (though that was probably overkill.)

Sorry there's so many pictures! There's just a bunch of neat things you can do with the function for the colors, and I didn't want to upload code for each one, so I took a lot of screenshots.

title: Female Banana Plug / Binding Post to 20mm T-Slot Holder

description.text:
This is a part for attaching female banana jacks / binding posts that you can buy online (I bought mine on Banggood) to a 20mm rail. I used this on my Kossel 3d printer to use my printer power supply for charging LiPo batteries.

Update (8 April, 2016): Changed banana-to-banana spacing to 3/4in to match standard spacing. Thanks ArizonaClark.

Force-Fit the Binding Posts

After printing, place the binding post washer into the front, align the flats on the binding posts with the 3d print, and push it in with a mallet or the edge of a table.

Designed in Solidworks, Student Edition.

Sorry guys, I designed this in Solidworks, Student Edition 2015. So I can't really share it without having the weird "education only" icon appear next to my part. It really is for education only.

comments.text: What's the spacing on the holes?  IIRC, "dual" banana plugs is 0.75 inches, center to center.  The dual plugs are available, but you'll often find adapters from BNC to banana plugs that have the standard spacing.
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: I have it as 18.670mm -> ~0.735in from empirical measurements.  It does fit the double banana connector that I have lying around.  Maybe there's enough slack in the 3d print to make up for the 15mils of difference?
comments.author: ArizonaClark

author: Leon22

description.text:
This is the next iteration of my original sumobot design. A few changes:
  • It\'s made from three pieces, not one
    *It uses two solarbotics GM8 gear motors (actually the pololu 120:1 equivalent), instead of continuous servos
  • It works.
    • I\'m really happy with how it came out. UPDATE
    I\'ve updated the files since I first posted this thing. They\'re pretty small tweaks but they really help when trying to wire up the whole thing and hold down the electronics. I've posted a video of it in action. It still has no opponent sensing/detection but it's staying within the white space perfectly. See it here:
    http://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/4281870587/in/set-72157622790238786/ Stay tuned for thorough instructions/code and possibly a chassis kit for sale at botmade.etsy.com

Print one of each part.
Bolt things together with m3 nuts and bolts.
Wire everything up.
Have fun!

description.text:
Second remix of the castle-tower_round :
First version, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1545593

This is a new version with modular system floor.
You can now add a floor (v1 or v2) over the basement or over the last floor.

Make a real dungeon.

OpenSCAD code (Add in castle-kit-1-8.scad & doblo-factory-1-11.scad needed) :


module tower_round_basement_with_gate ()
{
    $fs = 0.1;
    $fa = 4;

    // (col, row, up, width,length,height,nibbles_on_off) 

    heightBase = 1;
    heightGate = 12;
    heightWin = heightGate;
    overGate = 3;
    heightFloor = 6;
    overFloor = 3;
    heightBattlement = 6;
    heightTow = heightGate+overGate+heightFloor
    +overFloor+heightBattlement;
    posiBattlement = heightBase+heightTow
    -heightBattlement;
    widthGate = 3.5;
    widthWin = 2;
    posiFloor = heightBase+heightGate+overGate;

    base_plate (-4, -4, 0, 8, 8, heightBase, false);
    nibbles (-4, -1, 1, 8, 2);
    nibbles (-2, -2, 1, 4, 1);
    nibbles (-2,  1, 1, 4, 1);
    nibbles (-4, -4, 1, 1, 1);
    nibbles (-4,  3, 1, 1, 1);
    nibbles ( 3,  3, 1, 1, 1);
    nibbles ( 3, -4, 1, 1, 1);

    // tower structure
    difference () {
    union () {
        difference () {
        cyl_block (-4, -4, heightBase, 8, 8, heightTow, false) ;
        // carve it out
        cyl_block (-3, -3, heightBase-1, 6, 6, heightTow+2, false) ;
        // holes in the wall on top
        block (-5, -1, posiBattlement, 10,  2, heightBattlement+1, false) ;
        block (-1, -5, posiBattlement,  2, 10, heightBattlement+1, false) ;
        }
        // roof platform
        difference () {
        cyl_block (-3, -3, posiFloor, 6, 6, heightFloor, false) ;
        cyl_block (-3, -3, posiFloor-0.01, 6, 1, heightFloor-1, false) ;
        }
        nibbles (-2, -2, posiFloor+heightFloor, 4, 4);
        nibbles (-1, -3, posiFloor+heightFloor, 2, 1);
        nibbles (-1,  2, posiFloor+heightFloor, 2, 1);
        nibbles ( 2, -1, posiFloor+heightFloor, 1, 2);
        nibbles (-3, -1, posiFloor+heightFloor, 1, 2);

    }
    // doors, uses a "house form"
    house_lr (-5, -widthGate/2, 0, 10, widthGate, heightGate+heightBase) ;
    }
    // nibbles on battlement
    nibbles (-3,  2, heightTow+heightBase, 1, 1);
    nibbles (-3, -3, heightTow+heightBase, 1, 1);
    nibbles ( 2,  2, heightTow+heightBase, 1, 1);
    nibbles ( 2, -3, heightTow+heightBase, 1, 1);

}


module tower_round_floor_v1 ()
{
    $fs = 0.1;
    $fa = 4;

    // (col, row, up, width,length,height,nibbles_on_off) 

    heightBase = 0;
    heightGate = 6;
    heightWin = heightGate;
    overGate = 2;
    heightFloor = 6;
    overFloor = 3;
    heightBattlement = 6;
    heightTow = heightGate+overGate+heightFloor
    +overFloor+heightBattlement;
    posiBattlement = heightBase+heightTow
    -heightBattlement;
    widthGate = 3.5;
    widthWin = 2;
    posiFloor = heightBase+heightGate+overGate;

    // tower structure
    difference () {
    union () {
        difference () {
        cyl_block (-4, -4, heightBase, 8, 8, heightTow, false) ;
        // carve it out
        cyl_block (-3, -3, heightBase-1, 6, 6, heightTow+2, false) ;
        // holes in the wall on top
        block (-5, -1, posiBattlement, 10,  2, heightBattlement+1, false) ;
        block (-1, -5, posiBattlement,  2, 10, heightBattlement+1, false) ;
        }
        // roof platform
        difference () {
        cyl_block (-3, -3, posiFloor, 6, 6, heightFloor, false) ;
        cyl_block (-3, -3, posiFloor-0.01, 6, 1, heightFloor-1, false) ;
        }
        nibbles (-2, -2, posiFloor+heightFloor, 4, 4);
        nibbles (-1, -3, posiFloor+heightFloor, 2, 1);
        nibbles (-1,  2, posiFloor+heightFloor, 2, 1);
        nibbles ( 2, -1, posiFloor+heightFloor, 1, 2);
        //nibbles (-1,  2, posiFloor+heightFloor, 2, 1);
        nibbles (-3, -1, posiFloor+heightFloor, 1, 2);

    }
    // windows
    house_lr (-5, -widthWin/2, -1, 10, widthWin, heightWin+1) ;
    house_fb (-widthWin/2, -5, -1, widthWin, 10, heightWin+1) ;

    // negative nibbles on base
    posi = heightBase-0.5;
    #nibbles (-3,  2,  posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles (-3, -3,  posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles ( 2,  2,  posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles ( 2, -3,  posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles (-3,  2, 0.5+posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles (-3, -3, 0.5+posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles ( 2,  2, 0.5+posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles ( 2, -3, 0.5+posi, 1, 1);
    }

    // nibbles on battlement
    nibbles (-3,  2, heightTow+heightBase, 1, 1);
    nibbles (-3, -3, heightTow+heightBase, 1, 1);
    nibbles ( 2,  2, heightTow+heightBase, 1, 1);
    nibbles ( 2, -3, heightTow+heightBase, 1, 1);
}


module tower_round_floor_v2 ()
{
    $fs = 0.1;
    $fa = 4;

    // (col, row, up, width,length,height,nibbles_on_off) 

    heightBase = 0;
    heightGate = 6;
    heightWin = heightGate;
    overGate = 2;
    heightFloor = 6;
    overFloor = 3;
    heightBattlement = 6;
    heightTow = heightGate+overGate+heightFloor
    +overFloor+heightBattlement;
    posiBattlement = heightBase+heightTow
    -heightBattlement;
    widthGate = 3.5;
    widthWin = 2;
    posiFloor = heightBase+heightGate+overGate;

    // tower structure
    difference () {
    union () {
        difference () {
        cyl_block (-4, -4, heightBase, 8, 8, heightTow, false) ;
        // carve it out
        cyl_block (-3, -3, heightBase-1, 6, 6, heightTow+2, false) ;
        // holes in the wall on top
        block (-5, -1, posiBattlement, 10,  2, heightBattlement+1, false) ;
        block (-1, -5, posiBattlement,  2, 10, heightBattlement+1, false) ;
        }
        // roof platform
        difference () {
        cyl_block (-3, -3, posiFloor, 6, 6, heightFloor, false) ;
        cyl_block (-3, -3, posiFloor-0.01, 6, 1, heightFloor-1, false) ;
        }
        nibbles (-2, -2, posiFloor+heightFloor, 4, 4);
        nibbles (-1, -3, posiFloor+heightFloor, 2, 1);
        nibbles (-1,  2, posiFloor+heightFloor, 2, 1);
        nibbles ( 2, -1, posiFloor+heightFloor, 1, 2);
        //nibbles (-1,  2, posiFloor+heightFloor, 2, 1);
        nibbles (-3, -1, posiFloor+heightFloor, 1, 2);

    }
    // windows
    block (-5, -widthWin/2, -1, 10,  widthWin, heightWin+1, false) ;
    block (-widthWin/2, -5, -1, widthWin, 10, heightWin+1) ;

    // negative nibbles on base
    posi = heightBase-0.5;
    #nibbles (-3,  2,  posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles (-3, -3,  posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles ( 2,  2,  posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles ( 2, -3,  posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles (-3,  2, 0.5+posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles (-3, -3, 0.5+posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles ( 2,  2, 0.5+posi, 1, 1);
    #nibbles ( 2, -3, 0.5+posi, 1, 1);
    }

    // nibbles on battlement
    nibbles (-3,  2, heightTow+heightBase, 1, 1);
    nibbles (-3, -3, heightTow+heightBase, 1, 1);
    nibbles ( 2,  2, heightTow+heightBase, 1, 1);
    nibbles ( 2, -3, heightTow+heightBase, 1, 1);
}

This bearing block is a look a like the ones used on the Wanhao Duplicator i3 V 2.1.

You will need two LM8LUU long type bearings to replace the standard ones and 4 pcs M4 bushings (heat the bushings with an airgun before mounting to make them fit).

The tight fit will hold the bearing in place but you can also use 15mm bearing clips or 1mm zip ties to secure the LM8LUU in the bearing block.

comments.text:
What outside bearing diameter did you design this mount for?
Either not all LM8LUU are created equal or my printer needs tuning
I went with these: http://www.banggood.com/LM8LUU-8mm-Long-Type-Linear-Motion-Ball-Bearing-Slide-Bushing-CNC-Part-p-994394.html, which considering the price are obviously quality components :-)
The outside diameter for my bearing is 15mm and it fits very loosely inside the block. Definitely not press fit.
Also, I printed it "as is" which in retrospect might not be the best orientation. The layers are aligned such that it makes it very easy to snap the unsupported half circle.
I'll try to print it vertically tonight. But I thought I'd confirm that diameter first.

description.text:
A Pendulum Top Design for Science Outreach Experiments

The basic pendulum design is one of the simplest scientific instruments around, becoming more complex as scientists strived for increasing accuracy.

For a small science outreach demonstration, I've designed the upper parts of a pendulum. This needs to be supplemented by the rod and bob, and comprises two parts, the Rocker and the Base.

Design Description

The oval-shaped Rocker balances on two points which either can be printed (see the Rocker_Alt design) or from two self-tapping screws with a nice sharp point on them through the two 2mm diameter holes. I suspect that the alternative design with printed plastic sharp points will degrade over time due to wear on the tips more than using self-tapping screws. Generally a sharp point is needed in order to reduce the frictional forces on the pendulum and increase its Q-factor. The central hole is intended to accept a M4 all-thread bar which can be made the right length to hold the bob at the other end.

The Base may be clamped in a standard laboratory stand so that the pendulum can be hung off the side of a desk through its rectangular frame, held at the top by the Rocker balancing on two points.

It's early days at the moment with this design so sizes may change. Nevertheless I hope you find this useful and best wishes.
